instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_RESET: What is SMC_RESET? SMC_RESET is not a signal, it is an abbreviation for “SMC_RESET_L”, which is the signal someone is referring to when they type “SMC_RESET”  "SMC_RESET_L is a signal that resets the SMC when it is low(this is what the “_L” prefix means), and lets the SMC out of reset mode when it is high. .
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Greenlight sometimes.
threads.message:
These boards are my worst repair rate. I just don't understand them for some reason.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.20
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.422
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> = 3.418

Everything else is 0v. No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and onwards.

Every now and then when taking measurements it spins the fan for a second then stops again. It has a green light initially, but I think the adapter is just remembering that it had a green light when it was plugged in before. Once it goes out, I can't get it back till I plug it into a working laptop again.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Greenlight sometimes.
threads.message:
If I push the diagnostic / debug port, the board boots up. :/

Let go of the port, it switches off.

Just noticed the MagSafe light keeps going from Orange to green as I touch the board.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Greenlight sometimes.
threads.message: Remove the diagnostic port and I bet my domain name an MXL6406E is BIOS chip on this board.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Greenlight sometimes.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 15313"]I bet my domain name an MXL6406E is BIOS chip on this board.[/QUOTE]

haha. Yep, bang on.

What's the go with that chip and the debug port?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Greenlight sometimes.
threads.message:
Still experiencing the same behaviour.

Only starts when I press where teh diagnostics port used to be.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Greenlight sometimes.
threads.message: If the light goes green I bet the <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> is triggered. Measure what is going on.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Greenlight sometimes.
threads.message:
I measured on <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>::5.

It's low then goes high when I press the diagnostics port. A few moments later it starts up.

How do I fix this?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Greenlight sometimes.
threads.message:
Oh. <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> seems to be missing.

Is that a pull up resistor?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Greenlight sometimes.
threads.message:
Replaced <RESISTOR>R5110</RESISTOR>, ran a jumper from Pin 1(corroded away) to <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and boom.
She's happy again.

Mark solved please.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Greenlight sometimes.
threads.message:
Louis, would you mind expanding on the issue with the MXL chip? Does that particular SPI ROM chip cause power-related issues or something?

No thread Hijacking. Closed.
